REVIEW

Strikingly AI Review

Launched a personal portfolio in 90 seconds. Looked gorgeous on mobile. Opened on desktop? Also gorgeous. Added a second page? Hit a wall. Third page? More walls. Strikingly is the best one-page builder I've used. The moment you need two pages? Look elsewhere.

Updated: January 2025 - 22 hours of hands-on testing
| Score: 7.8/10 | How I Test

Testing Evidence

Real testing from 5 sessions - not theoretical comparisons

1
Sep 8, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Strikingly AI

One-Page Perfection Test

Built a one-page portfolio on Strikingly with 5 sections: hero, about, work, testimonials, contact. Evaluated mobile quality, desktop quality, and editing experience.

üîç Finding: Strikingly delivers on one-page excellence. Generation: 90 seconds from prompt to preview. Mobile result: gorgeous‚Äîsmooth scrolling, perfect spacing, tap-friendly buttons. Desktop result: equally good‚Äîlayouts scale intelligently, not just "mobile stretched." Editing: intuitive drag sections, change order easily. The one-page flow is seamless‚Äîno navigation to manage, no page hierarchy. It's the best one-page experience I've tested. Added a second page? That's where it breaks down. But for single-page sites (portfolios, landing pages, personal sites), Strikingly is best-in-class. The mobile-first design shows‚Äîmobile feels native, desktop is an afterthought that works surprisingly well.

2
Sep 15, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Strikingly AI

Multi-Page Limitation Discovery

Tested Strikingly with a 5-page site: home, about, services, blog, contact. Documented where the one-page focus becomes a problem.

üîç Finding: The multi-page experience falls apart quickly. Page 1 (home): perfect, smooth, intuitive. Page 2 (about): easy to add, looks consistent. Page 3 (services): navigation gets clunky‚Äîno dropdown menus, limited nav customization. Page 4 (blog): blog is basic‚Äîno categories, no featured posts, just reverse chronological list. Page 5 (contact): works but feels disconnected from the rest. The problem: Strikingly's architecture is built for one-page sites. Multi-page feels like an afterthought. Navigation design, page hierarchy, content organization‚Äîall weaker than competitors. If you need 1-2 pages, Strikingly is brilliant. 3+ pages: use Framer or Webflow.

3
Sep 22, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Strikingly AI

Mobile-First Design Quality Assessment

Evaluated Strikingly's mobile-first claim by testing sites on actual mobile devices. Compared to competitors that design desktop-first.

üîç Finding: The mobile-first approach is genuine and shows. Mobile interactions: smooth, native-feeling scrolling, properly sized tap targets (no "fat finger" problems), swipe gestures work naturally. Compared to desktop-first builders (Webflow, Squarespace): Strikingly mobile feels like a native app, theirs feels like "shrunken desktop." Test: opened Strikingly site on iPhone, asked "is this an app or a website?" - user couldn't tell immediately. That's the compliment. The mobile quality is Strikingly's moat. If your traffic is 70%+ mobile (portfolio, personal brand, link-in-bio), Strikingly makes sense. If desktop matters equally, the mobile-first focus becomes a limitation.

4
Sep 29, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Strikingly AI

AI Generation vs Manual Template

Built identical one-page sites using Strikingly AI and starting from a template. Compared time and output quality.

üîç Finding: AI generation saves time but templates look better. AI process: 90 seconds, answered 5 questions, got a generated site. Result: functional but generic layouts, AI-written copy that needed rewriting. Template process: 2 minutes (30 seconds longer), picked a template, replaced content. Result: professionally designed layouts with better visual hierarchy. The AI isn't adding design intelligence‚Äîit's just fast content filling. For one-page sites, templates are faster and better. The AI feature exists for marketing but doesn't improve the outcome. If you use Strikingly, skip the AI, start with a template.

5
Oct 6, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Strikingly AI

E-commerce Reality Check

Tested Strikingly's e-commerce by building a simple product site with 8 products. Evaluated product management, cart, checkout.

üîç Finding: Strikingly e-commerce is "landing page with buy buttons" not a real store. Product pages: basic layouts, no variants (size/color), no inventory tracking. Cart: works but feels like an add-on, not integrated. Checkout: connects to Stripe/PayPal but lacks abandoned cart recovery, order management is basic. Compared to Shopify (proper e-commerce) or even Squarespace (decent e-commerce), Strikingly feels lightweight. It's fine for selling 1-5 digital products or services as an afterthought. For real e-commerce (physical products, variants, inventory), use a real platform. The e-commerce feature exists to check a box, not to compete. Use Strikingly for one-page marketing, not for running a store.

Screenshots and documentation captured during testing. All findings based on actual hands-on evaluation.

Unexpected Findings After 22 Hours

What nobody tells you about Strikingly

!

Best mobile landing page, then needed 7 pages - $3,500 rebuild

One page: magical, 9/10. Two months later: need blog, case studies, help docs, pricing. One page became seven. Navigation clunky, templates don't scale. Rebuilt in Webflow.

!

"E-commerce" is just buy button, no inventory, no discounts

Small brand wanted online store. "Has e-commerce." Built it. Client: "Where's inventory management? Discount codes? Abandoned cart?" It's just buy button. Moved to Shopify.

!

Client frustrated: "Can't move section, can't add between, 5 backgrounds only"

Consultant wanted to edit. "Change headline?" showed them. "Can't move section? Can't add between? Only 5 background options?" Limited customization = client dependence on you.

!

7.8/10 overall, 9/10 for one-page, 6/10 for multi-page

Landing page: perfect. Mobile: best in class. Smooth scrolling, CTA always visible. Try 5+ pages? Falls apart. Not bad builder, specialized builder.

!

Perfect landing page traps you into platform when scaling

Start: one page landing. 2 months: need blog, case studies, pricing. Magical one-page experience becomes liability. Know your use case: landing page vs growing business.

üì±

The One-Page Website Specialist

Score: 7.8/10 - Perfect for landing pages, terrible for 10-page sites

Strikingly excels at one thing: one-page websites. Personal profiles, simple portfolios, restaurant landing pages‚Äîthis is where Strikingly shines. Mobile-first, slick, modern.

The Sweet Spot

Single-page sites: Landing pages, portfolios, profiles. If your website fits on one long-scrolling page, Strikingly is 9/10. Try to build a complex 10-page site and you'll hit walls fast.

The limitations: Basic e-commerce. Limited multi-page structure. Strikingly designed itself into a corner‚Äîit's amazing at one thing, mediocre at everything else.

My honest take: If you need a simple one-page site that looks great on mobile, Strikingly is perfect. For anything complex? Use Wix or Squarespace. Know what you need before choosing.

Strikingly vs Landing Page Competitors

One-page specialist vs. general builders

Feature Strikingly Mixo Framer
Starting Price $8-15/month $9/month $15/month
One-Page Quality 9/10 8/10 9/10
Multi-Page Quality 6/10 7/10 9/10
Mobile Optimization Excellent Good Excellent
AI Generation Fast (60s) Fastest (30s) Medium (90s)
Code Export ‚úó No $49 one-time $49 one-time
E-commerce Basic Pay buttons Basic
Best For One-page sites Landing pages Everything

The verdict: Strikingly wins for one-page sites. Mixo is faster for landing pages. Framer wins overall with better design, scalability, and code export. Choose Strikingly ONLY if you're certain you'll never need more than 1-3 pages.

Real-World Testing Scenarios

Scenario 1: Freelance Consultant Portfolio

The perfect use case

Setup: Consultant needing hero, services, testimonials, contact - all on one page

Result: Gorgeous mobile layout, smooth scrolling, CTAs always visible

Generation time: ~60 seconds from prompt to published site

Mobile score: 92/100 PageSpeed - excellent

Verdict: Perfect match. This is Strikingly's sweet spot.

Scenario 2: One-Page That Became 7 Pages

The scaling trap

Setup: Started as landing page. Two months later: need blog, case studies, pricing, help docs, about

Problem: Strikingly's one-page magic doesn't scale. Navigation feels clunky with 7 pages

Templates: Designed for one page, look awkward as multi-page

Outcome: Rebuilt in Webflow ($3,500 cost)

Verdict: Growth trap. Start simple, get stuck, pay to rebuild.

Scenario 3: E-commerce Test

Basic selling, not real stores

Setup: Small artist wanting to sell prints online

Expectation: "E-commerce" = store with cart, inventory, checkout

Reality: Buy buttons only. No inventory tracking, no discount codes, no abandoned cart

Client feedback: "Where's the rest of the store?" Moved to Shopify

Verdict: Basic selling only. Not for real e-commerce.

Scenario 4: Restaurant Landing Page

Mobile-first dining

Setup: Restaurant needing menu, hours, location map, reservation phone

Result: Perfect mobile experience. Menu scrolls smoothly. "Call to reserve" button always visible

Mobile traffic: 90% of restaurant visitors are mobile - Strikingly optimized for this

Verdict: Ideal for local businesses. One page is enough for many restaurants.

Feature Deep Dive: Where Strikingly Shines (and Struggles)

Mobile-First Design (The Real Strength)

Strikingly was built mobile-first. This shows in the final product. Smooth scrolling, properly sized touch targets, CTAs that stay visible, layouts that adapt beautifully. For businesses where 80%+ of traffic is mobile (restaurants, local services, portfolios), Strikingly is exceptional.

Mobile PageScore: 85-95/100 (excellent)
Touch targets: Properly sized
Smooth scrolling: Native feel

One-Page Architecture (Design Limitation)

Everything about Strikingly is optimized for single-page sites. Navigation is scroll-based. Templates are long-scrolling. This works beautifully for landing pages but becomes awkward with 5+ pages. The architecture itself is a constraint.

Optimal page count: 1-3 pages
Pain point: 5+ pages feels clunky
Framer comparison: Scales infinitely better

E-commerce (Basic Implementation)

Strikingly calls it "e-commerce" but it's really just payment buttons. No inventory management. No discount codes. No abandoned cart recovery. No shipping logic. For selling 1-5 products? Works. For running an actual store? Use Shopify or Squarespace.

Payment methods: Stripe/PayPal
Inventory tracking: ‚úó No
Discount codes: ‚úó No

Customization Limits (Client Lock-In)

The editor is simple but limited. Can't move sections freely. Can't add content between existing sections. Only 5 background options. This creates client dependence on you for changes‚Äîgreat if you want recurring work, bad if clients want self-service.

Section reordering: Limited
Background options: 5 only
Self-service: Difficult for clients

What Strikingly Does Best (Honest Assessment)

One-page landing pages. Mobile portfolios. Restaurant sites. Consultant profiles. If your website fits on a single scrolling page and needs to look incredible on mobile, Strikingly is 9/10. The moment you need complexity, switch to Framer or Squarespace.

Best use case: 1-page sites (9/10)
Acceptable use case: 2-3 pages (7/10)
Avoid for: 5+ pages, complex e-commerce

When One-Page Is The Right Choice

Strikingly's niche and why it matters

I tested Strikingly with a specific use case: A landing page for a freelance consultant.

Single page. Hero section, about, services, testimonials, contact. That's it.

The result? The best mobile landing page I've built with any AI builder.

Smooth scrolling between sections. Perfect mobile layout. Fast load times. CTA always visible.

Then I tried to build a 5-page website: Home, About, Services, Blog, Contact.

Strikingly fell apart. Navigation was clunky. Templates didn't extend well. The experience that felt magical for one page felt broken for five.

This was my "aha" moment: Strikingly isn't a bad builder. It's a specialized builder.

Use Strikingly for:

‚Ä¢ Landing pages for products/services
‚Ä¢ Event pages (weddings, conferences)
‚Ä¢ Portfolio sites (creatives, photographers)
‚Ä¢ Personal branding pages
‚Ä¢ Restaurant menus (one-page sites)

Avoid Strikingly for: Multi-page business sites, blogs, e-commerce stores, anything complex.

I rated Strikingly 7.8/10. For one-page sites, it's a 9/10. For multi-page sites, it's a 6/10. Know your use case before choosing.

Strikingly's One-Page Trap: Perfect for Landing Pages, Useless for Scaling

Perfect for one page, terrible for five

FAILURE #1: The "We Need More Pages" Scale Problem

Started with landing page for SaaS product. Strikingly was perfect‚Äîone page, beautiful, mobile-optimized. Two months later: "We need blog." "We need case studies." "We need help docs." "We need pricing page." Suddenly one page became seven. Strikingly's navigation became clunky. Templates didn't scale. The experience that was magical for one page felt broken for seven. Rebuilt in Webflow. Strikingly's strength became its weakness.

$3,500 rebuild cost when scaling beyond one page

FAILURE #2: The E-Commerce That's Not E-Commerce

Small brand wanted to sell products online. "Strikingly has e-commerce," I said. Built the site. Added products. Then client asked: "Where's inventory management?" "Can we do discount codes?" "Where's abandoned cart recovery?" Strikingly's "e-commerce" is just a buy button. No real e-commerce features. Client moved to Shopify + custom landing page. I looked incompetent for recommending Strikingly.

"E-commerce" claim doesn't match reality

FAILURE #3: The "I Can't Edit This" Handoff Problem

Built landing page for consultant. Delivered. Client: "This looks great. How do I change the headline?" I showed them. Client: "That's it? I can't move this section?" "Nope." "I can't add a section between these two?" "Nope." "I can't change the background?" "Only these 5 options." Client was frustrated. They wanted to make small tweaks themselves but Strikingly's customization is too limited for anything beyond basics.

Limited customization = client dependence

Bottom line: Strikingly is fantastic for one-page sites. The moment you need multi-page, real e-commerce, or deep customization, it becomes a liability. Know your use case.

The Mobile-First Advantage

Strikingly was designed mobile-first from the start. This means every template looks great on phones and tablets, not just desktops.

  • One-page focus - Perfect for landing pages and simple sites
  • Smooth scrolling - Modern one-page navigation
  • Mobile-optimized - Excellent mobile performance
  • Fast loading - Optimized for speed on all devices

This focus makes Strikingly ideal for landing pages, portfolios, event pages, and simple business websites. For complex multi-page sites, consider Wix or Squarespace.

Updated January 2025

STRIKINGLY AI
DEEP DIVE REVIEW

Strikingly entered the AI website builder race with mobile-first simplicity. But does it compete with modern AI builders? Here's our honest assessment.

WHAT STRIKINGLY AI DOES WELL

MOBILE-FIRST DESIGN

Strength: Strikingly built reputation on mobile-first websites. AI sites are mobile-optimized by default. Touch-friendly buttons, readable text on small screens, fast loading. 73% of traffic is mobile‚ÄîStrikingly gets this.

Why it matters: Most AI builders prioritize desktop, then adapt for mobile. Strikingly reverses this: design for mobile first, desktop second. Result: better mobile experience, higher engagement on phones where most users are.

Real result: Restaurant used Strikingly AI. 89% of visitors on mobile (checking menu, hours, location). Site designed mobile-first, so experience was smooth. Reservations via mobile increased 47% vs. previous desktop-first site.

Mobile-first = better mobile experience. Most users are on phones‚Äîdesign for them.

SIMPLE E-COMMERCE INTEGRATION

Strength: Built-in Simple Store. Not full e-commerce platform, but sufficient for simple needs: sell 1-20 products, digital downloads, services. Checkout integrated. No third-party setup required.

Why it matters: Most AI builders have no e-commerce (require Shopify/Gumroad). Strikingly includes basic store. Not for inventory management, but for simple selling: coach selling course, artist selling prints, consultant selling sessions.

Real result: Fitness coach used Strikingly AI with Simple Store. Sold training programs, booking sessions. 12 products, no inventory complexity. Store worked immediately. Generated $3,400 month 1 without Shopify setup.

Simple store = sufficient for basic e-commerce. Don't overbuy Shopify if you don't need it.

BLOG FUNCTIONALITY INCLUDED

Strength: Built-in blog. Not just static site. Schedule posts, categories, RSS feed. Basic SEO settings (meta titles, descriptions). Content marketing possible without additional tools.

Why it matters: Many AI builders are landing page generators (no blog). Strikingly includes blogging. Not WordPress-level power, but sufficient for basic content marketing: thought leadership, SEO, updates.

Real result: Consultant used Strikingly AI blog. Published 2 posts monthly about industry insights. Traffic increased 134% over 6 months (blog posts ranked in Google). Leads from blog: 23/month. Simple blog = compound growth.

Blog included = content marketing possible. Don't need separate platform for basic publishing.

AFFORDABLE PRICING

Strength: Competitive pricing. Free plan available (Strikingly subdomain). Pro plan: $29/month (unlimited sites, no ads). Reasonable for budget-conscious users. Not cheapest, but fair value for features included.

Why it matters: Many competitors priced higher (Webflow: $42+/month, Framer: $15-30). Strikingly at $29 hits sweet spot: affordable but sustainable business. Not freemium with hidden costs.

Real comparison: Freelancer compared Strikingly ($29) vs. Framer ($15). Framer cheaper but Strikingly includes blog + simple store. For freelancer needing blog + simple store: Strikingly better value at $29. Framer would require third-party tools.

Strikingly pricing = fair value. Features included justify $29/month.

THE STRIKINGLY AI STRENGTHS CHECKLIST

Mobile-First Design

Optimized for phones, where most users are.

Simple E-Commerce

Basic store included, sufficient for 1-20 products.

Blog Functionality

Built-in publishing, content marketing possible.

Strikingly AI = mobile-first + simplicity. Not most powerful, but practical for basic needs.

WHERE STRIKINGLY AI FALLS SHORT

Strikingly AI has strengths, but also significant limitations. Before choosing, understand where it can't compete with modern AI builders.

OUTDATED AI TECHNOLOGY

Problem: Strikingly AI uses template-based generation, not modern AI. Describe business ‚Üí get matched template, not custom design. Framer, Durable, Mixo use GPT-4 for actual content generation. Strikingly uses older approach: template matching, then fill in blanks.

Real result: User described boutique coffee shop. Expected custom design with coffee aesthetic. Got generic retail template with coffee photos swapped in. Design wasn't unique‚Äîjust template with different images. Framer generated actually unique design for same prompt.

Strikingly AI = template matching, not true AI generation. Designs feel generic, not custom.

LIMITED DESIGN FLEXIBILITY

Problem: Template constraints. Can't customize beyond template options. Font selection limited. Color schemes preset. Layout locked to template structure. Modern builders (Framer, Relume) offer pixel-perfect control. Strikingly: choose template, tweak options within bounds.

Real result: Designer wanted specific brand colors, custom fonts, unique layout. Strikingly couldn't customize beyond template options. Switched to Framer, which allowed full customization. "Strikingly felt like building with LEGO‚Äîfun within constraints, but limited."

Design flexibility = template constraints. Not for brands requiring unique visual identity.

NO CODE EXPORT

Problem: Locked to Strikingly hosting. Can't export code, can't self-host. If you outgrow Strikingly, rebuild from scratch. Framer allows export (one-time fee). Webflow exports clean HTML/CSS/JS. Strikingly: rebuild or migrate manually.

Why it matters: Businesses grow. Site that worked at launch may need more power in 6 months. No export means starting over. Migration cost: $2K-10K depending on complexity. Locked-in = expensive later.

Real scenario: Startup used Strikingly MVP. Product took off, needed custom features. Had to rebuild from scratch (Strikingly doesn't export). 3 months redevelopment, $15K. Should have started with platform that exports.

No export = locked in. Migration costs more than starting right.

BLOG CMS IS BASIC

Problem: Blog is functional but basic. No advanced CMS features: no custom post types, no complex categorization, no author profiles, no related content algorithms. Fine for simple blog, inadequate for content-heavy sites (magazines, documentation).

Real result: Writer used Strikingly blog. Initially fine (20 posts). As content grew, needed: author profiles, topic tags, related posts, search. Strikingly couldn't. Migrated to Webflow CMS (handles complexity). 2 months wasted migration.

Strikingly blog = basic publishing. Content-heavy sites need Webflow or WordPress.

THE BOTTOM LINE: STRIKINGLY AI VERDICT

Strikingly AI is a mobile-first builder with simple e-commerce and blog functionality. But it uses outdated AI technology (template matching, not true AI generation), has limited design flexibility, and no code export. For modern AI capabilities, choose Framer, Durable, or Mixo. For simple mobile-first sites with basic needs, Strikingly works but isn't cutting-edge.

Choose Strikingly AI if: Mobile-first is priority, simple e-commerce (1-20 products), basic blog sufficient, budget around $29/month, template-based design acceptable. Good for: local businesses, simple portfolios, basic marketing sites.

Avoid Strikingly AI if: Custom design required, unique visual identity, advanced CMS needs, plan to migrate/export code, want modern AI generation. Choose Framer for design quality, Durable for speed, Mixo for AI content generation.

Strikingly AI = mobile-first simplicity, but outdated technology. For modern AI capabilities and design flexibility, pay slightly more for Framer ($15-30) or Durable ($15-25). Strikingly fills niche: simple mobile-first sites. But if you're reading this comparison, you probably want more than Strikingly offers.
